name: SAND VERBENA
description: bracts (small leaf-like structures) 0.5 to 1 inch long; fruit 0.25 to 0.5 inch long; perianth 0.5 to 1.5 inch long; the limb white or purplish and ~ 0.5 inch long; leaves deltoid to oblong or lanceolate; sprawling plant with whitish sticky stems and heads of white or pinkish heads of fragrant flowers.
habitat: common on plains on sandy soil extending to foothills.

name: WILD ONION
common_name: plains onion, early onion, textile onion
description: inflorescence (flower cluster) erect; leaves 2 per scape (leafless flower stalk).

name: BIG BLUESTEM
description: flower cluster three-parted, resembling an upside-down turkey foot.

name: DWARF  PUSSYTOES
description: usually with leafy stolons; leaves in basal rosette, white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding composite head) white or sometimes pinkish tips.

name: RED THREE-AWN
description: glumes (basal empty bracts - small leaf-like structures - enclosing the base of grass spikelet - smallest flower cluster) unequal, the first half as long as the second.
habitat: dry hills, disturbed sited at 2,700 to 7,600 feet elevation.

name: FRINGED MOUNTAIN SAGE
common_name: fringed sage, silver sage, wormwood, pasture sage
description: leaves finely dissected, silvery-hairy; flowering stems erect.
habitat: dry meadows and slopes at 3,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: PRAIRIE SAGE
description: leaves silver white to greenish.
habitat: dry plains, roadcuts at 4,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: DWARF MILKWEED
description: leaves crowded, string-like and not obviously whorled.

name: SHOWY MILKWEED
description: hoods (whorl of floral parts between petals and stamens) broadest at the base and tapering upwards; leaves oblong to lance-ovate (lance-shaped to egg-shaped).

name: FIELD MILKVETCH
description: blunt keel; flowers erect, clustered in ovoid heads; pubescence basifixed (hairs attached at the base).
habitat: grasslands on the plains and mesas.

name: FOUR-WINGED SALTBUSH
description: shrubby throughout; fruit bracts (small leaf-like structures) with the margins spreading apart, creating four wings; plant widely and stiffly branched.
habitat: sagebrush zone and greasewood flats on the plains and San Luis Valley; sandy and alkaline areas at 4,000 to 8,000 feet.

name: SIDEOATS GRAMA
description: spikelets form on one side of the stem.
habitat: plains and outwash mesas of the Front Range, rocky hills, slopes at 3,200 to 7,400 feet elevation.

name: FALSE BONESET
description: Stem leaves toothed or if entire, linear to lanceolate and acute; flowering branches elongate and spreading

name: MUSK THISTLE
description: heads with disk flowers only; pappus (extension of the ovary in sunflower family) barbellate (with short barbs); outer phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - that subtend a composite flower head) spreading-reflexed (bent backwards).
habitat: neglected fields, overgrazed meadows and roadsides.

name: FOOTHILLS PAINTBRUSH
description: calyx incised equally above and below; bracts (small leaf-like structures) broad and more conspicuous than calyx (sepals); leaves and stems tomentose (covered with wooly, multidirectional hairs); bracts orange.
habitat: grasslands of the foothills from Rocky Flats south; South Park.

name: BLUE GRAMA
description: spike forms at the end of the rachis (axis of the flower); long hairs at the collar (where the blade joins the sheath - the part that surrounds the stem - of a grass leaf).
habitat: grasslands of the plains, foothills, and intermountain parks at 3,200 to 9,700 feet elevation.

name: HORSEWEED
description: ray flowers minute, rarely exceeding the involucre (cluster of bracts - small leaf-like structures - at the base of flower cluster; in sunflowers, phyllaries); leaves linear, alternate, crowded on stem; heads numerous in diffuse panicles (branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).

name: PLAINS LARKSPUR
description: stems single or a few together, not densely clustered.
habitat: mesas, grasslands, dry open woods; sandy hills, brushlands.

name: BRANCHING ERIGERON
description: flowers numerous and pinkish; pappus (hair-like extension of the ovary) of ray and disk flowers alike; stem pubescence (hairs) widely spreading; stems with relatively few branches.

name: WHIPLASH DAISY
common_name: whiplash erigeron, trailing daisy, trailing fleabane
description: stolons ( horizontal stems that take root as in the strawberry) rooting at the tips; stem hairs appressed (lying flat); pappus (hairlike extension of the ovary) of 2 rows of bristles of different lengths.
habitat: dry meadows at 6,500 to 10,500 feet elevation.

name: DWARF FLEABANE
description: stem and leaf pubescence (hairs) spreading; plant forms a dense clump; leaves twisted, sticky and hairy.

name: REDSTEM FILAREE
description: carpel (seed pod section) tails hairy on inner side; leaves pinnately compound.

name: WESTERN WALLFLOWER
description: siliques (mustard fruits) and pedicels (stalks) densely gray-pubescent (hairy); siliques spreading at a wide angle to the stem.
habitat: open areas, slopes, meadows, valleys at 4,500 to 12,500 feet elevation.

name: SCARLET GAURA
description: flowers with parts in fours; inferior ovary (petals attached at top of ovary); stem ascending, seldom erect.
habitat: dry grasslands, roadsides, sagebrush, lower altitudes.

name: VELVETY GAURA
description: plant with spreading branches at the top; sepals 1.5 - 3 mm long; petals 1.5 - 2 mm long.

name: GUMWEED
description: cauline leaves oblong and sessile by a broad, clasping base; pappus (extension of the ovary) bristles smooth; phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - on the lower portion of the composite head) recurved and sticky.

name: SNAKEWEED
description: low and bushy growth form; phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding flower heads in the sunflower family) covered with a sticky exudate.
habitat: dry sites at low altitudes (4,000 to 7,000 feet).

name: COMMON SUNFLOWER
description: phyllaries (exterior bracts - small leaf-like structures - of composite heads) hispid-ciliate (clothed with stiff bristle-like hairs along the margins); phyllaries with acuminate tips (drawn out into a long tip); leaves ovate.

name: PRAIRIE SUNFLOWER
description: phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head) lanceolate (lance-shaped), appressed hairy (with flattened hairs) and not ciliate (marginally fringed with hairs).

name: BUSH SUNFLOWER
common_name: dwarf sunflower, perennial sunflower, little sunflower
description: leaves with petioles (stalks), mostly opposite (arising in pairs from same points on stem), ovate (egg-shaped); plant many-stemmed from base.

name: FAIRY TRUMPET
common_name: skyrocket, scarlet gilia (red form), white gilia
description: ovary with 3 locules (compartments); corolla (petals) salverform (with a long narrow tube opening into a wider cup i.e. trumpet-shaped).

name: WINTERFAT
description: hairy, white-mealy, spiny plant with inconspicuous greenish flowers, forming large pure stands on gravelly benches in the lower river valleys.
habitat: Gravelly benches in lower river valleys; dry environments, such as sunny slopes, sandy plains, and alkali flats at 4,000 to 9,500 feet.

name: PRICKLY LETTUCE
description: pappus (extension of the ovary) bright white; leaf margins and/or midrib and veins spiny.

name: SAND LILY
description: leaves grasslike; tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) united into a tube.

name: GAYFEATHER
description: pappus (hair- or scale-like extension of the ovary) plumose (having feathery side branches) to the naked eye; flowers 3 - 8 per head; plant with several stems.
habitat: dry, open slopes and roadsides from 5,000 to 8,000 feet elevation.

name: BROAD-LEAVED DALMATIAN TOADFLAX
description: leaves ovate (egg-shaped), glabrous (hairless) and glaucous (contains white waxy covering); corolla (collective term for petals) spurred.

name: NARROW-LEAF PUCCOON
common_name: fringed gromwell, fringed puccoon, narrowleaf gromwell, narrowleaf stoneseed, puccoon
description: corolla (petals) tube 3 - 4 times longer than the calyx (sepals); corolla salverform (trumpet-shaped); corolla lobes fringed.

name: SILVERY LUPINE
description: tip of keel (lower petal in pea family) long and slender, erect or slanting forward; leaves are palmately compound (divided like a hand); leaflets often conduplicate (folded lengthwise).

name: SKELETONWEED
description: much-branched, almost leafless plant; heads with ray flowers only.

name: BIGELOW'S TANSY ASTER
common_name: tansy aster, purple tansy aster, sticky aster
description: plants branched only in the inflorescence; leaves spiny or divided.

name: ALFALFA
description: leaves pinnately trifoliate (divided into three with a stalked terminal leaflet); flowers in heads.
habitat: escaped from cultivation; found on roadsides.

name: FOOTHILL MERTENSIA
description: leaves with less than 2 pairs of prominent veins in stem leaves; filaments attached near the top of the cylindrical corolla tube and projecting beyond the junction of the tube and expanded portion of the flower.

name: PRAIRIE EVENING PRIMROSE
description: leaves broad and deeply pinnitafid (pinnately cleft into unstalked segments), wooly and grayish.

name: MARBLESEED
description: leaves with stiff, appressed hairs; flowers form a cone with style protruding.

name: PRICKLY-PEAR CACTUS
description: pads very spiny, not wrinkled; fruits dry and withering soon after ripening.
habitat: sunny, rocky slopes at 3,500 to 7,200 feet elevation.

name: LAMBERT LOCO
description: keel (lower boat-shaped petal in the pea family) tip is pointed; calyx with appressed (lying flat) hairs; some of foliage hairs dolabriform (2-armed or pick-like).
habitat: grasslands of the plains, mountain parks and foothills at 4,500 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: ROCKY MOUNTAIN LOCO
description: keel (lower boat-shaped petal in the pea family) tip is pointed with a purple spot.
habitat: gravelly areas of open meadows and slopes.

name: ONE-SIDED PENSTEMON
description: leaves glaucous (contains white waxy covering).

name: WINGED BUCKWHEAT
description: basal leaves oblanceolate (lance-shaped, with the broadest part at the apex); flower cluster a panicle (repeatedly branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: open hillsides, mesas and mountain parks.

name: PRAIRIE CONEFLOWER
description: grows upright, freely branching in an open clump; leaves strigose (covered with sharp-pointed straight hairs which lay flat); leaves with narrow divisions.

name: THREE-LEAF SUMAC
description: arching branches form dense, rounded shrub.  Red, hairy fruits; 3-parted leaves resemble poison ivy, to which skunkbrush is related, on a smaller scale.
habitat: canyonsides and rimrock at 4,000 to 8,000 feet elevation.l

name: WOODS ROSE
description: leaflets 5 - 7; flowering stems with broad-based thorns, occasional bristles; sepals 2 mm wide at base.
habitat: valleys, gulches, trailsides at 6,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: PRICKLY RUSSIAN THISTLE
description: leaves rigid, spine-tipped; plant with stiffly spreading branches, very spiny and not easily handled.

name: BROOM SENECIO
description: foliage mostly glabrous; phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below composite heads) about 8.

name: COWBOY'S DELIGHT
common_name: copper mallow, scarlet globemallow, scarlet falsemallow
description: lower leaves very deeply palmately (like a hand) divided, silvery from dense, stellate (star-shaped) hairs.
habitat: roadsides, disturbed areas at 4,500 to 8,500 feet elevation.

name: WIRELETTUCE
description: achenes smooth or nearly so, only longitudinally ribbed; plants low or tall; lower leaves usually disappearing by flowering time.
habitat: canyons, rocks, openings, sandy, gravelly washes and slopes in desert shrub comunities, juniper woodlands, open sandy short-grass prairie.

name: COLORADO GREENTHREAD
description: heads rayless or the very few rays are very short and inconspicuous.
habitat: generally distributed on the plains and outwash mesas.

name: YELLOW SALSIFY
description: flowers shorter than the phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head); peduncles (stalk of a flower cluster) swollen in fruit.

name: MULLEIN
description: leaves decurrent (base of leaves continue down the stem beyond the point of attachment); foliage woolly-pubescent (covered in dense hair-like wool).

name: COMMON VERVAIN
description: conspicuous floral bracts (small leaf-like structures) leaflike, equalling or exceeding the flowers; flowers in spikes; plant prostrate (lying flat on the ground).

name: NUTTALL VIOLET
description: leaves narrowly lanceolate (lance-shaped) or lance-elliptic (oval), at least 3 times long as wide.
habitat: meadows, open slopes, often blooming in the protection of rocks at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: MANY-FLOWERED ASTER
common_name: heath aster, tufted white prairie aster
description: closely packed overlapping white flowers are distinctive; involucre (bracts - small leaf-like structures - that subtend a flower cluster; in sunflowers known as phyllaries) less than 0.25 inch tall; ray-flowers less than 20; stem hairs appressed or ascending.
habitat: dry ground along roads and fences, on sandy hillsides, and in openings in woods.

name: WHITE ASTER
description: involucre (cluster of bracts - small leaf-like structures - at the base of flower cluster; in sunflowers, phyllaries) more than 0.25 inch tall; ray flowers 20 - 30 or more; stem hairs spreading.

name: COWPEN DAISY
description: Up to 2' tall, smelly, with much branched hairy grayish stem.

name: YUCCA
description: flowers erect, drooping only in age; flowers in simple, narrow panicles (repeatedly branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: rocky areas on the plains and foothills; found up to 8,500 feet elevation.
